Germany | language = English | budget = $8 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=monster.htm|title=Monster (2003) - Box Office Mojo|publisher=}}. Dir. [[Patty Jenkins]] stated in an interview on 13 November 2017 with film critic Thelma Adams that press accounts of the film's budget were exaggerated, saying that the budget was $1.5 million. | gross = $60.4 million }} '''''Monster''''' is a 2003 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[Crime film|crime]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] written and directed by [[Patty Jenkins]]. The film is about [[serial killer]] [[Aileen Wuornos]], a former [[Prostitution|prostitute]] who was [[Capital punishment|executed]] in Florida in 2002 for killing six men (she was not tried for a seventh murder) in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Wuornos was played by [[Charlize Theron]]; her semi-fictionalized lover, Selby Wall (based on Wuornos's real-life girlfriend Tyria Moore), was played by [[Christina Ricci]]. Theron received critical acclaim and won numerous awards for her portrayal, including the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]], [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress]] and the [[Screen Actors Guild Award]]s for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role|Outstanding Lead Actress]]. ''Monster'' was produced by [[Denver & Delilah Films]] and K/W Productions and distributed by [[Newmarket Films]].{{cite web|last1=Rooney|first1=David|title=Monster|url=https://variety.com/2003/film/awards/monster-2-1200537925/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=November 17, 2003|accessdate=17 November 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Honeycutt|first1=Kirk|title=Monster|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr/reviews/review_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=2030577|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=November 18, 2003|accessdate=17 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031231212039/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr/reviews/review_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=2030577|archivedate=December 31, 2003}} ==Plot== In 1989, after moving from [[Michigan]] to [[Daytona Beach, Florida]], [[Prostitution|prostitute]] [[Aileen Wuornos]] meets Selby Wall in a [[gay bar]]. Although she is initially hostile and declares that she is not [[gay]], Aileen talks to Selby over a drink of beer. Selby takes to Aileen almost immediately, as she likes that she is very protective of her. Selby invites Aileen to spend the night with her. The two women return to the house where Selby is staying (temporarily exiled by her parents following the accusation from another girl that Selby tried to kiss her). They later agree to meet at a [[roller skating]] rink, and they kiss for the first time. Aileen and Selby fall in love, but they have nowhere to go, so Selby goes back to her aunt's home. After being violently [[Rape|sexually assaulted]] and brutalized by a client, Vincent Corey, Aileen kills him in self-defense and decides to quit prostitution. She confesses her actions to Selby, who has been angry with her for her failure to support both of them. Aileen struggles to find legitimate work, but because of her lack of qualifications and criminal history, prospective employers reject her and are occasionally openly hostile. Desperate for money, Aileen returns to prostitution. She robs and kills her [[Procuring (prostitution)|johns]], each killed in a more brutal way than the last, as she is convinced that they are all trying to rape her. She spares one man out of pity when he admits he has never had sex with a prostitute, but eventually kills another man who, instead of exploiting her, offers help. Aileen uses the money she stole from her victims to support herself and Selby. However, Selby reads in the newspapers about the string of murders, and she begins to suspect that Aileen may have committed them. She confronts Aileen, who justifies her actions by claiming she had only been protecting herself. Horrified, Selby returns to [[Ohio]] on a charter bus. The night of her arrest, Aileen is approached by two [[bounty hunters]] luring her outside to hand her to the cops. Thomas, whom Aileen always referred to as the only friend she had, tries to save her from getting arrested by stealing her away from the two men that approached her. Thomas offers to drive her off but Aileen declines, no longer trusting herself with the well-being of anyone dear to her. Aileen is eventually arrested at a [[biker bar]] and speaks to Selby one last time while in jail. Selby reveals some incriminating information over the telephone and Aileen realizes that the police are listening in. To protect Selby and Thomas, Aileen admits that she committed the murders alone. During Aileen's trial, Selby testifies against her, with Aileen's loving consent. Aileen is convicted of the murders and [[Death penalty|sentenced to death]]. On October 9, 2002, Aileen is executed by [[lethal injection]]. ==Cast== * [[Charlize Theron]] as [[Aileen Wuornos]] * [[Christina Ricci]] as Selby Wall (based on Tyria Moore) * [[Bruce Dern]] as Thomas * [[Lee Tergesen]] as Vincent Corey (based on Richard Mallory) * [[Annie Corley]] as Donna * [[Pruitt Taylor Vince]] as Gene / Stuttering "John" * [[Marco St. John]] as Evan / Undercover "John" * [[Marc Macaulay]] as Will / Daddy "John" * [[Scott Wilson (actor)|Scott Wilson]] as Horton / Last "John" * [[Kane Hodder]] as Undercover cop * [[Brett Rice]] as Charles ==Reception== Film critics praised ''Monster''; most gave overwhelmingly high praise to Theron's performance as a [[Mental illness|mentally ill]]''[[Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer]]''. Dir. [[Nick Broomfield]] and Joan Churchill. Columbia TriStar Home Entertainment. 2003. woman – Wuornos had [[antisocial personality disorder]] and [[borderline personality disorder]].{{cite web|url=http://www.clarkprosecutor.org/html/death/US/wuornos805.htm|title=Aileen Carol Wuornos #805|publisher=}} For the role, Theron gained {{convert|30|lb}}, shaved her eyebrows, and wore [[prosthetic]] teeth.{{cite web | url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/slideshow/Movie-transformations-49438/photo-3487212.php | title=Movie transformations | publisher=SFGate | date=November 1, 2012 | accessdate=1 June 2014}} Critics called her performance, and her makeup, a "transformation".{{cite web | title = Monster | publisher = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1128647-monster/ | accessdate = 2007-06-12}} Film critic [[Roger Ebert]] named it best film of the year, and wrote "What Charlize Theron achieves in Patty Jenkins' 'Monster' isn't a performance but an embodiment... [It] is one of the greatest performances in the history of the cinema."{{cite news | last = Ebert | first = Roger | coauthors = | title = ''Monster'' | work = | pages = | publisher = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date = January 1, 2004 | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20040101/REVIEWS/40310032/1023 | accessdate = 2010-02-06 }} Ricci's performance also drew some praise, but was not without criticism. In his review for the film, Ebert praised her performance, stating "Christina Ricci finds the right note for Selby Wall – so correct some critics have mistaken it for bad acting, when in fact it is sublime acting in its portrayal of a bad actor. She plays Selby as clueless, dim, in over her head, picking up cues from moment to moment, cobbling her behavior out of notions borrowed from bad movies, old songs, and barroom romances". However, several people who knew Aileen, criticised the movie for portraying her as a victim and portraying her victims as villains.https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/opinions/2004/02/08/more-of-a-monster-than-hollywood-could-picture/179c7282-5e25-4eb5-8980-c72aa90efdb0/?noredirect=onhttps://abcnews.go.com/2020/GiveMeABreak/story?id=124320&page=1 Theron won the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]], [[Golden Globe Award]] for [[List of Golden Globe Awards: Film, Best Actress, Drama|Best Actress in a Drama]] and the [[Screen Actors Guild#SAG Awards|SAG Award]] for her performance. In 2009, Ebert named it the third best film of the decade.{{cite web |title = The Best Films of the Decade |first = Roger |last = Ebert |authorlink = Roger Ebert |url = http://www.rogerebert.com/rogers-journal/the-best-films-of-the-decade |work = rogerebert.com |date = December 30, 2009 | accessdate = June 19, 2013 }} Review website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 81% of critics gave the film a positive review, with a "Certified Fresh" and an average score of 7.2/10. The site's critical consensus states: "Charlize Theron gives a searing, deglamorized performance as real life serial killer Aileen Wuornos in ''Monster'', an intense, disquieting portrait of a profoundly damaged soul." ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Monster | type = soundtrack | artist = [[BT (musician)|BT]] | cover = Monster OST.jpg | alt = | released = January 30, 2004 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = | label = dts Entertainment | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} In 2004, [[BT (musician)|BT]] released a [[soundtrack]] to the film.{{cite web |url=http://www.soundtrack.net/albums/database/?id=3435 |title=Monster Soundtrack |publisher=[[SoundtrackNet]] |accessdate=2007-06-17| date=August 4, 2004}} Included with the release is a DVD featuring all fifteen original cues, and an additional nine cues that would not fit on the CD, as well as an interview with BT and Patty Jenkins, and remix files for "Ferris Wheel". {{more citations needed|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox video game |title = Monster Rancher 3 |image = monsterrancher3.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = North American PlayStation 2 cover art |developer = [[Tecmo]] |publisher = [[Tecmo]] |designer = |series = ''[[Monster Rancher]]'' |released = {{vgrelease|JP|March 22, 2001|NA|September 24, 2001}} |genre = [[Life simulation game]] |modes = [[Single player]], or [[Multiplayer game|two players versus]] |platforms = [[PlayStation 2]] }} '''''Monster Rancher 3''''' (known in Japan as {{nihongo|'''''Monster Farm 3'''''|モンスターファーム3|Monsutā Fāmu Surī}}) is the third game in [[Tecmo]]'s [[Monster Rancher]] series. It is the first game in the [[Monster Rancher|''Monster Rancher'' series]] for the [[PlayStation 2]].
==Differences== This game uses [[cel-shaded]] graphics to give the game a more cartoon-like feel. However, the player may still generate monsters by inserting a disc into the PS2. Furthermore, ''Monster Rancher 3'' is the first game in the series to allow players the ability to generate monsters based on past discs, as well as monsters already bred. As an example, once a monster has been bred, from that point on one can simply generate them from their Monster Encyclopedia, saving the gamer unnecessary time and trouble having to remember and find discs that generated various monsters. Also, ''Monster Rancher 3'' is the first and currently only ''Monster Rancher'' game to allow players to trade monster data. By inserting memory cards for both players, it is possible to transfer monsters in one player's Monster Encyclopedia to another player's file.
==Characters==
===General===
====Fleria==== A young Tochikan girl who serves as your guide throughout the story. Never leaving your side, she acts as though you couldn't possibly survive without her help, but it is revealed that she needed your help to become a breeder in the first place. She is somewhat bossy, but is kind nonetheless. She harbors a dislike for Gadamon and was mentored by "Ms." Jenna.
====Bragma==== Bragma is Fleria's grandfather who runs the Monster Shrine. He is slightly stubborn, but wise. He has a past which he seems a little embarrassed by.
====Mucchi==== A peddler. He sells various items and is the messenger to tell the player about regions which he/she has unlocked.
====Gadamon==== Fleria's rival. Very arrogant, and often shows up merely to antagonise the two of you. She is a breeder also, and so challenges you to fights every so often.
====Rip and Rap==== Two young sisters whom Fleria used to be friends with. They have held a grudge against her for years about various types of food.
====Date==== A rich, spoiled, slightly arrogant man who offers to buy land from the player for 10,000 g. Despite his arrogance, he does turn out to be a good man.
===Morx===
====Mitia==== A young breeder who considers the player and Fleria worthy rivals. Despite her politeness, Fleria seems to dislike her.
====Mosha==== An experienced breeder who knows the area well. She appears very elderly and has a somewhat romantic past with Bragma. Her nephew is Taz.
====Taz==== A seemingly cocky yet decent young male breeder. He is particularly fond of Beaklons, which causes problems for Fleria and the player. He is Mosha's nephew.
====Yukiyo==== A very uncofident new female breeder whom Fleria dislikes, claiming that she makes her "tired."
===Kalaragi===
====Lek==== A laidback male breeder whom Fleria appears to like. Despite his laidback nature, he gets very upset about losing. He appears to have some sort of connection with Jimsey.
====Sansha==== Sansha is a young female breeder who uses the area used by the player as a fishing area. She seems to pay more attention to fishing than to breeding. Her monster names generally only have two letters (i.e. Mo).
====Jimsey==== A strange and sneaky boy who loves money. At a point in the game, he steals from the player, but he turns out to be decent.
===Takrama===
====Haz==== A very serious male breeder who is very fond of Fleria. He is pursuing a "bad monster trainer." He was mentored by Lus.
====Shimuka==== A laidback yet feisty female breeder. She, like Haz, is pursuing a "bad monster trainer," which makes her attack the player and Fleria, but she makes amends with them.
====Lus==== An old man and native of Takrama. Haz's mentor. He is originally thought to be the bad monster trainer, but the accusation is false. He seems to like golems.
===Brillia===
====Maya==== A good-natured and generous young female breeder. Taya's older sister. Her family owns the land that the player uses to train. She was attacked by the "modified monster."
====Taya==== Originally an extremely shy young boy, after battling with the player and Fleria, he becomes more outgoing. He is Maya's younger brother. He was attacked by the modified monster.
====Nahze==== A scientist in the field of monster modification. He created a mysterious Zan monster, which causes people trouble. He appears to be a bit naive.
===Goat===
====Burn==== Burn, also known as Lord Burn, is a somewhat arrogant yet decent breeder who has some connection with Jenna.
====Jenna==== An experienced breeder who was Fleria's mentor. She appears protective of Fleria, though she is not afraid to start a fight.
====Kai==== A bad character who is connected to a "Joker" monster. Jenna cautions against him, though Fleria doesn't listen.
====Dagga==== An unknown man who is strongly connected to the monster, Joker. He is some kind of a friend to Kai.
==Adaptation and region== Making up for the loss of the combination system is the ability of monsters to adapt to their surroundings. Though only one is available at the start of the game, the five different homes that you can raise your monster in represent five climates, each with its own training regimes, features, and food.
Morx, the first region you will train in, is a clearing in a [[forest]] centered around a gargantuan tree. The grassy area is covered with mushrooms, allowing the monster to train by interacting with the tree and the fungi.
Takrama, an oasis in the middle of a barren [[desert]], features rocky terrain, cacti, and dust storms with which to test your monster. It is noted that this is the harshest environment for monsters.
Brillia, a frozen [[tundra]], is filled with snow, seals, and icicles. A lone tree sits near the end of the area.
Kalaragi, a bright [[rainforest]], centers around a giant waterfall (known in-game as Umbagi, but rarely referred to by its name). A cliff path leads behind the waterfall Umbagi up to a ledge, and there is a giant lilypad accompanied by a similarly large [[Lotus (plant)|lotus]] flower. Crocodiles inhabit the water. *Note: There is a bug in Kalaragi. If you lose to Gadamon, Sansha will direct you to a place near the "Lord" Monster. If you search the area, Fleria will direct you to another spot, and the storyline will halt.
Goat, the oddly named underwater sanctuary, allows you to raise your monster underwater. The waters of Goat are extremely high in [[oxygen]], explaining why and how you and your monsters have no trouble living under the sea.
Each monster is affiliated with one of these regions, and has subspecies corresponding to each climate and area. For instance, the Suezo - a monster normally inclined to Takrama – also has a subspecies for Goat, the sharklike Fukazo.
When a monster of one subspecies is raised in another area, after a time, they will mature. If they have been fed with enough of the regional food, they will adapt to their surroundings and change subspecies. For example, if a Morx Mocchi is raised in Brillia, and fed enough of Brillia's local food, the Mocchi will adapt to its surroundings, turning blue and white to blend in with its new home, and become a Brillian Mocchi.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 77/100<ref name=MC>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/monster-rancher-3 |title=Monster Rancher 3 for PlayStation 2 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=June 6, 2016}}</ref> | Allgame = {{Rating|3.5|5}}<ref>{{cite web |last=Miller |first=Skyler |url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=33099&tab=review |title=Monster Rancher 3 - Review |publisher=[[AllGame]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141115085931/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=33099&tab=review |archivedate=November 15, 2014 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=June 6, 2016}}</ref> | EGM = 7/10<ref>{{cite journal |author=EGM staff |title=Monster Rancher 3 |magazine=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |date=November 2001 |page=210}}</ref> | GI = 9.25/10<ref>{{cite journal |last=Reiner |first=Andrew |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/Games/Review/200111/R03.0805.1733.35849.htm |title=Monster Rancher 3 |magazine=[[Game Informer]] |issue=103 |date=November 2001 |page=100 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080620004641/http://www.gameinformer.com/Games/Review/200111/R03.0805.1733.35849.htm |archivedate=June 20, 2008 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=June 6, 2016}}</ref> | GMaster = 68%<ref>{{cite journal |title=Monster Rancher 3 |magazine=[[GamesMaster (magazine)|GamesMaster]] |year=2001}}</ref> | GSpot = 8.4/10<ref>{{cite web |last=Torres |first=Ricardo |date=September 21, 2001 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/monster-rancher-3-review/1900-2814059/ |title=Monster Rancher 3 Review |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=June 6, 2016}}</ref> | GSpy = 82%<ref>{{cite web |last=Padilla |first=Raymond |date=November 10, 2001 |url=http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/october01/monsterrancher3/ |title=Monster Rancher 3 |publisher=[[GameSpy]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041215123329/http://archive.gamespy.com/reviews/october01/monsterrancher3/ |archivedate=December 15, 2004 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=June 6, 2016}}</ref> | IGN = 7.9/10<ref>{{cite web |last=Smith |first=David |date=September 27, 2001 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/09/27/monster-rancher-3 |title=Monster Rancher 3 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=June 6, 2016}}</ref> | OPM = {{Rating|4|5}}<ref>{{cite journal |title=Monster Rancher 3 |magazine=[[Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine]] |date=November 2001 |page=155}}</ref> | PSM = 7/10<ref>{{cite journal |title=Review: Monster Rancher 3 |magazine=[[PlayStation: The Official Magazine|PSM]] |date=November 2001}}</ref> }}
The game received "generally favorable reviews", albeit less than the previous two games in the series, according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]].<ref name=MC/>

'''Muhammadu Kudu Abubakar Ubandoma III''' (died 30 March 2014) was appointed Etsu (Ruler) of the [[Agaie Emirate]], a [[Nigerian traditional states|traditional state]] based in [[Agaie]] in [[Niger State]], [[Nigeria]] on 30 April 2004.<ref name=tday19>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisdayonline.com/archive/2004/05/01/20040501news19.html |work=This Day |date=2004-05-01 |title=Kure Names New Emir of Agaie |author=Jide Orintunsin |accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref><ref>http://www.dailytimes.com.ng/article/emir-agaie-died-age-52</ref>
Abubakar, who was 42 when appointed Emir, is the son of the 10th Emir of Agaie, Alhaji Abdullahi Bello Ubandoma. He earned a Higher Diploma in Animal Health and Husbandry and a Postgraduate Diploma in Public Administration from [[Ahmadu Bello University]], [[Zaria]].<ref name=tday19/> He is grand patron of the Nuhu Lafarma (Education) Foundation, which promotes improved education in the Agaie Emriate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lafarmafoundationagaie.com/aboutus.html |publisher=Nuhu Lafarma (Education) Foundation |title=THE FOUNDATION |accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref> He is one of the promoters of formation of a new Edu State from parts of the current [[Niger State|Niger]] and [[Kwara State|Kwara]] states as a homeland for the [[Nupe people]], with capital at [[Bida, Nigeria|Bida]]. The movement is led by the [[Bida Emirate|Emir of Bida]], [[Abubakar Yahaya]], and is also supported by the [[Lapai Emirate|Etsu Lapai]], [[Umar Baogo III]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.compassnewspaper.com/~compas/NG/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=22684:bankole-endorses-call-for-creation-of-edu-state-from-niger-kwara&Itemid=7966 |title=Bankole endorses call for creation of Edu State from Niger, Kwara |date=16 July 2009 |author=HOPE AFOKE ORIVRI |work=Nigerian Compass |accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref>
In January 2010 Abubakar conferred the honorary title of "Badakoshin Agaie" on the Niger State governor [[Muazu Babangida Aliyu]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201001120514.html |title=Governor Aliyu Warns Traditional Rulers Against Partisan Politics |work=Vanguard |author=Wole Mosadomi |date=12 January 2010 |accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref> In July 2010 he was attacked in Agaie by an angry mob who accused him of siding with the police after local people had tried to prevent police from pursuing suspected criminals. In the ensuing violence one person was killed, and later the mob carried his body to the Etsu's palace.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://peoplesdaily-online.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9868:mob-attacks-emir-of-agaie-for-siding-with-the-police&catid=16:national-news&Itemid=33 |title==Mob attacks Emir of Agaie for siding with the Police |date=21 July 2010 |author=Aideloje Ojo, |work=Peoples Daily |accessdate=2010-09-11}}</ref>

{{Expand Japanese|川崎市中1男子生徒殺害事件|November 2015|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Ryōta Uemura | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 2002 | birth_place = [[Nishinoshima, Shimane|Oki Islands]], [[Japan]] | death_date = {{BirthDeathAge|df=yes| |2002| | |2015}} | death_place = [[Kanagawa Prefecture]], Japan }} {{nihongo|'''Ryōta Uemura'''|上村 遼太|Uemura Ryōta|2002–2015}} was a 13-year-old Japanese boy who was tortured and murdered in [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa|Kawasaki]], [[Kanagawa Prefecture]]. His body was discovered in the [[Tama River]] on Friday, February 20, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/politics/view/abe-expresses-shock-at-murder-of-kawasaki-boy |title=Abe expresses shock at murder of Kawasaki boy ‹ Japan Today: Japan News and Discussion |publisher=Japantoday.com |date=2015-02-06 |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/crime/view/police-arrest-18-year-old-youth-over-murder-of-kawasaki-boy |title=Police arrest 3 youths over murder of Kawasaki boy ‹ Japan Today: Japan News and Discussion |publisher=Japantoday.com |date=2015-02-06 |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref> On February 25, 2015, the police arrested three boys in relation with Uemura's murder. Two of the suspects told the police that the alleged ringleader was inspired by [[Jihadi John]]'s killings. It is unclear whether any of the three arrested suspects was the ringleader.<ref name="japantimes1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/social_affairs/AJ201502270067 |title=Police arrest 3 teens in slaying of junior high student - AJW by The Asahi Shimbun |publisher=Ajw.asahi.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ensor |first=Josie |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/11438814/Police-in-Japan-arrest-teenager-for-Islamic-State-inspired-beheading.html |title=Police in Japan arrest teenager for 'Islamic State-inspired' beheading |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/teenager-held-for-isinspired-murder-in-japan-20150227-13r5yc.html |title=Teenager held for 'IS-inspired' murder in Japan |publisher=Smh.com.au |date=2013-10-24 |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/02/26/national/crime-legal/ex-schoolmate-received-message-via-line-app-slain-boys-cellphone-near-time-death/#.VPE6SI5hIs4 |title=Friend got Line message from slain Kawasaki boy near time of death |publisher=The Japan Times |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/02/24/national/crime-legal/police-suspect-multiple-weapons-were-used-in-boys-stabbing-death-in-kawasaki-2/#.VPE6Zo5hIs4 |title=Murdered Kawasaki boy may have been victim of bullying |publisher=The Japan Times |date=2015-02-24 |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/views/editorial/AJ201502280027 |title=EDITORIAL: How come no one saw the warning signs before boy was slain? - AJW by The Asahi Shimbun |publisher=Ajw.asahi.com |date≤= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref> The same two suspects also provided details of the circumstances of Uemara's murder.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/social_affairs/AJ201503020043|title=Teen admits he killed Kawasaki boy, alleges involvement of two others|work=AJW by The Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/03/02/national/crime-legal/key-suspect-boys-slaying-kawasaki-said-starting-come-clean/|title=Kawasaki suspect says he beat, stabbed 13-year-old victim|work=The Japan Times|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150302p2g00m0dm030000c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150309122855/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150302p2g00m0dm030000c.html |archivedate=2015-03-09 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/english/news/20150302_11.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304214505/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/english/news/20150302_11.html |archivedate=2015-03-04 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150303p2a00m0na007000c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-03 |deadurl=yes web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2015/03/04/editorials/society-failed-save-uemura/|title=Society failed to save Uemura|work=The Japan Times|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150304p2a00m0na010000c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402111603/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150304p2a00m0na010000c.html |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }}</ref>
Prior to his death, Uemura had apparently been refusing to commit crimes for a group of older boys with whom he spent time, and wanted to cut ties with them. At the time of his death, his mother was working as a nurse to support her children.<ref name="japantimes1">{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/02/27/national/crime-legal/several-boys-grilled-simultaneously-kawasaki-boys-death/ |title=Several boys to be grilled simultaneously over Kawasaki boy's death |publisher=The Japan Times |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/02/27/national/crime-legal/arrest-warrants-issued-3-boys-kawasaki-teens-murder/ |title=Three teen suspects held in Kawasaki boy's slaying |publisher=The Japan Times |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/02/21/national/crime-legal/police-probe-murder-male-youth-found-near-kawasaki-river/ |title=Naked body of 13-year-old stabbing victim found near Kawasaki river |publisher=The Japan Times |date=2015-02-21 |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref>
==Victim== Uemura was well known among his friends as a cheerful boy. When he stopped going to school, his teacher called his parents to see if anything was wrong.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/perspectives/news/20150303p2a00m0na004000c.html|title=Editorial: Murder of Kawasaki boy a wake-up call for adults|work=mainichi.jp|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/views/vox/AJ201503030031|title=VOX POPULI: Boy's life lost after society failed to understand his world|work=AJW by The Asahi Shimbun|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref> After his parents divorced, his mother raised him and his four siblings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150305p2a00m0na017000c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150308002809/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150305p2a00m0na017000c.html |archivedate=2015-03-08 |df= }}</ref>
==Reaction== Japanese Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] expressed his condolences to the victim's family and vowed that Japan should not have another similar tragedy. It was the third shocking incident in 2015, after a 19-year-old college student killed 77-year-old Tomoko Mori.<ref>{{cite web|author=NHK (Japan Broadcasting Corporation) |url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/english/news/20150226_21.html |title=Juvenile crime down, recidivism up - News - NHK WORLD - English |publisher=.nhk.or.jp |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150228p2g00m0dm022000c.html |title=1 of 3 teen suspects allegedly attacked Kawasaki boy prior to murder - 毎日新聞 |language=ja|publisher=Mainichi.jp |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=NHK (Japan Broadcasting Corporation) |url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/english/news/20150227_18.html |title=Abe in shock over teen murder - News - NHK WORLD - English |publisher=.nhk.or.jp |date= |accessdate=2015-02-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.j-cast.com/tv/2015/03/02229139.html|title=18歳少年「上村遼太さん殺害」自供！「チクられて頭にきた」|work=J-CASTテレビウォッチ|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref> On March 5, 2015, after Uemura's mother released statements about her son's death,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/crime/view/kawasaki-murder-victims-mother-releases-statement-to-media|title=Kawasaki murder victim's mother releases statement to media ‹ Japan Today: Japan News and Discussion|work=japantoday.com|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref> the three boys previously arrested were charged with murder.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150305p2a00m0na018000c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150308112111/http://mainichi.jp/english/english/newsselect/news/20150305p2a00m0na018000c.html |archivedate=2015-03-08 |df= }}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} '''Offences Against the Person Act''' (with its variations) is a stock [[short title]] used for legislation in the [[United Kingdom]], in the [[Republic of Ireland]], in [[Hong Kong]], in [[New Zealand]], in [[Tasmania]] and in [[Antigua and Barbuda]], relating to [[offences against the person]]. It seems to have been derived from the [[long title]] of the Act which has come to be known as the [[Offences Against the Person Act 1828]]. It is sometimes abbreviated to '''OAPA''', as in "OAPA 1861".
The Bill for an Act with this short title will have been known as a '''Offences Against the Person Bill''' during its passage through Parliament.
"Offences Against the Person Acts" may be a generic name either for legislation bearing that short title or for all legislation which relates to offences against the person. It is not a term of art.
==List== ===United Kingdom=== *The [[Offences Against the Person Act 1828]] *The [[Offences Against the Person (Ireland) Act 1829]] *The [[Offences Against the Person Act 1837]] *The [[Offences against the Person Act 1861]] *The [[Offences against the Person Act 1875]]
===Republic of Ireland=== *The [[Non-Fatal Offences against the Person Act 1997]]
===Hong Kong=== :The [[Offences against the Person Ordinance 1865]] (No. 2)<ref name=hkgaz>(1913) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XxtBAQAAMAAJ 59] Hong Kong Government Gazette: Supplement 156</ref> :The [[Offences against the Person (Amendment) Ordinance 1913]]<ref name=hkgaz/> :The [[Offences against the Person (Amendment) Ordinance 1982]]<ref>(1982) Hong Kong Government Gazette, Legal Supplement No 1, p A-127 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Lrw8AQAAIAAJ]</ref>, CAP 212<ref>[http://www.hklii.org/hk/legis/en/ord/212/ CAP 212 Offences Against the Person Ordinance]</ref>
The Offences against the Person Ordinances 1865 and 1913 is the [[collective title]] of the Offences against the Person Ordinance 1865 and the Offences against the Person (Amendment) Ordinance 1913.<ref name=hkgaz />
===New Zealand=== *The [[Offences against the Person Act 1866]] (30 Vict No 19)<ref>Statutes of New Zealand. Sir George Grey, Governor. Wellington. 1866. [https://books.google.ie/books?pg=PA83&id=JgNCAQAAMAAJ&output=html Page 83] et seq.</ref> *The [[Offences against the Person Act 1867]]<ref>Alexander James Johnston. Government Printer. 1902. p 621.</ref> *The [[Offences against the Person Act 1899]]<ref>Statutes of Tasmania: 1826-1901. Government Printer. 1902. p 625.</ref>

'''Olson's Extinction''' was a [[mass extinction]] that occurred {{mya|273}} in the early Guadalupian of the [[Permian]] period and which predated the [[Permian–Triassic extinction event]].<ref name="SahneyBenton2008RecoveryFromProfoundExtinction"> {{cite journal | ref = harv | last1=Sahney | first1 = S. | last2 = Benton | first2 = M.J. | title=Recovery from the most profound mass extinction of all time | journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences | year=2008 | volume = 275 | issue=1636 | pages = 759–65 | pmid=18198148 | pmc=2596898 | doi=10.1098/rspb.2007.1370 | url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/royprsb/275/1636/759.full.pdf }} </ref> [[Everett C. Olson]] noted{{When|date=April 2012}} that there was a hiatus and a sudden change in between the early Permian and middle/late Permian faunas. Since then this event has been realized across many groups, including plants, marine invertebrates, and tetrapods.
== Identification == The first evidence of extinction came when [[Everett C. Olson]] noted a hiatus between early Permian faunas dominated by [[pelycosaurs]] and [[therapsid]] dominated faunas of the middle and late Permian. First considered to be a preservational gap in the fossil record, the event was originally dubbed 'Olson's Gap'.<ref name=LSG04> {{cite journal | ref = harv |last=Lucas |first=S. G. |title=A global hiatus in the Middle Permian tetrapod fossil record |journal=Stratigraphy |year=2004 |volume=1 |pages=47–64 | url = http://www.micropress.org/stratigraphy/pdfs/Stratigraphy_1.1.47.pdf }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | ref = harv |last=Ivakhnenko |first=M. F. |title=Comparative survey of Lower Permian tetrapod faunas of eastern Europe and South Africa |journal=Paleontological Journal |year=2005 |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=66–71}}</ref> To compound the difficulty in identifying the cause of the 'gap', researchers were having difficulty in resolving the uncertainty which exists regarding the duration of the overall extinction and about the timing and duration of various groups' extinctions within the greater process. Theories emerged which suggested the extinction was prolonged, spread out over a several million years<ref name="wardetal"> {{ cite journal|vauthors=Ward PD, Botha J, Buick R, De Kock MO, Erwin DH, Garrison GH, Kirschvink JL, Smith R|last-author-amp=yes|year=2005|title=Abrupt and Gradual Extinction Among Late Permian Land Vertebrates in the Karoo Basin, South Africa|journal=Science|volume=307|issue=5710|pages=709–714|doi=10.1126/science.1107068|pmid=15661973 |bibcode = 2005Sci...307..709W }} </ref> or that multiple extinction pulses preceded the [[Permian–Triassic extinction event]].<ref name="SahneyBenton2008RecoveryFromProfoundExtinction"/><ref name=Retallack2006>{{cite journal | author = Retallack, G.J. |author2=Metzger, C.A. |author3=Greaver, T. |author4=Jahren, A.H. |author5=Smith, R.M.H. |author6= Sheldon, N.D. | year = 2006 | title = Middle-Late Permian mass extinction on land | journal = Bulletin of the Geological Society of America | volume = 118 | issue = 11–12 | pages = 1398–1411 | doi=10.1130/B26011.1 |bibcode = 2006GSAB..118.1398R }}</ref><ref> {{ cite journal|vauthors=Rampino MR, Prokoph A, Adler A |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2000|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(2000)28<643:TOTEEH>2.0.CO;2|title=Tempo of the end-Permian event: High-resolution cyclostratigraphy at the Permian–Triassic boundary|journal=Geology|volume=28|issue=7|pages=643–646|issn=0091-7613 |bibcode = 2000Geo....28..643R }} </ref> The impact of Olson's Extinction amplified the effects of the [[Permian–Triassic extinction event]] and the final extinction killed off only about 80% of species alive at that time while the other losses occurred during the first pulse or the interval between pulses.
During the 1990s and 2000s researchers gathered evidence on the biodiversity of plants, marine organism and tetrapods that indicated an extinction pulse preceding the [[Permian–Triassic extinction event]] had a profound impact on life on land. On land Sahney and Benton showed that even discounting the sparse fossil assemblages from the extinction period, the event can be confirmed by the stages of time bracketing the event since well preserved sections of the fossil record from both before and after the event have been found and they referred to the event as 'Olson's Extinction'.<ref name="SahneyBenton2008RecoveryFromProfoundExtinction" /> The 'Gap' was finally closed in 2012 when Michael Benton confirmed that the terrestrial fossil record of the Middle Permian is well represented by fossil localities in the American southwest and European Russia and that the gap is not an artifact of a poor rock record since there is no correlation between geological and biological records of the Middle Permian.<ref name=MJB2012A> {{cite journal |last=Benton |first=M.J. |title=No gap in the Middle Permian record of terrestrial vertebrates |journal=Geology |year=2012 |volume=40 |issue=4 |doi=10.1130/g32669.1 | url=http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/early/2012/03/01/G32669.1.abstract |pages=339–342 |bibcode=2012Geo....40..339B}}</ref>
Despite the closure of Olson's Gap, the presence of an extinction event at the Kungurian/Roadian boundary was still disputed. It was argued that the observed decrease in diversity might be due to the shift in the location of greatest sample size from the palaeo-equatorial to the palaeo-temperate regions: equatorial regions tend to have a higher diversity in most modern groups.<ref name=Benson2013>{{cite journal|last1=Benson|first1=R.|last2=Upchurch|first2=P.|title=Diversity trends in the establishment of terrestrial vertebrate ecosystems:Interactions between spatial and temporal sampling biases|journal=Geology|date=2013|volume=41|pages=43–46|doi=10.1130/g33543.1|bibcode=2013Geo....41...43B}}</ref> However, a thorough review of the tetrapod-bearing formations during the Kungurian and the Roadian found evidence that the faunal turnover at this time is not a result of the shift in sampling locality; the early Permian temperate faunas are more similar to the early Permian equatorial faunas than the middle Permian temperate faunas.<ref name=Brocklehurst2017>{{cite journal|last1=Brocklehurst|first1=N.|last2=Day|first2=M.|last3=Rubidge|first3=B.|last4=Frobisch|first4=F.|title=Olson's Extinction and the Latitudinal Biodiversity Gradient|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B|date=2017|volume=284|pages=20170231|doi=10.1098/rspb.2017.0231}}</ref> It was also shown that throughout the Permian, the highest diversity was found in temperate regions rather the equatorial, and therefore the fall in diversity could not be due to increased sampling of temperate latitudes.<ref name=Brocklehurst2017/>
== Possible causes == There is no widely accepted theory for the cause of Olson's Extinction. Recent research has indicated that climate change may be a possible cause. Extreme environments were observed from the Permian of Kansas which resulted from a combination of hot climate and acidic waters particularly coincident with Olson’s Extinction.<ref name=ZAMBITO2013> {{cite journal | author = Zambito J.J. IV. |author2=Benison K.C | year = 2013 | title = Extreme high temperatures and paleoclimate trends recorded in Permian ephemeral lake halite | journal = Geology | volume = 41 |issue=5 | pages = 587–590 | doi=10.1130/G34078.1 | bibcode=2013Geo....41..587Z }}</ref> Whether this climate change was a result of Earth's natural processes or exacerbated by another event is unknown.
== Extinction patterns ==
=== On land ===
====Plants==== Plants showed large turnover in the mid-to-late Permian and into the Triassic. The duration of higher extinction rates (>60%) in land plants was about 23.4 Myr, starting from Olson's Extinction and into the early Middle Triassic.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Xiong|first1=C.|last2=Wang|first2=Q.|title=Permian–Triassic land-plant diversity in South China: Was there a mass extinction at the Permian/Triassic boundary?|journal=Paleobiology|date=2011|volume=37|issue=1|pages=157–167|doi=10.1666/09029.1}}</ref> Olson's Extinction represents the third highest peak of extinction rates seen in plants throughout the Paleozoic, and the number of genera fell by 25%. .<ref name=CascalesMinana2015> {{cite journal | author = Cascales-Minana, B. | author2 = Diez, J.B. | author3 = Gerrienne, P. | author4 = Cleal, C.J. | year = 2015 | title = A palaeobotanical perspective on the great end-Permian biotic crisis | journal = Historical Biology | volume = 28 | pages = 1066–1074 | doi=10.1080/08912963.2015.1103237 }}</ref> The extinction was particularly severe among free-sporing plants; seed plants seem to have been largely unaffected.<ref name=CascalesMinana2015/>
====Tetrapods==== The Permian was a time of rapid change for tetrapods; in particular there was a major changeover from faunas dominated by basal synapsids ("[[pelycosaurs]]”) and reptiliomorphs ([[Diadectes]]) to faunas dominated by [[therapsid]]s ([[Dinocephalia]], [[Anomodontia]], [[Gorgonopsia]], and [[Cynodontia]]) some of which were direct ancestors of mammals.<ref name="MJB2012A" /> In 2008 Sahney and Benton<ref name="SahneyBenton2008RecoveryFromProfoundExtinction" /> confirmed that this was not just a turnover (gradual replacement of one faunal complex by another) but a real extinction event in which a significant drop in the biodiversity of tetrapods on a global scale and community level occurred. The extinction appears to have taken place in two phases: [[Edaphosauridae]] and [[Ophiacodontidae]] died out across the Kungurian/Roadian boundary, while Caseidae and Therapsida diversified; later in the Roadian [[Sphenacodontidae]] died out and Caseidae went into decline.<ref name=Brocklehurst2013>{{cite journal|last1=Brocklehurst|first1=N.|last2=Kammerer|first2=C. F.|last3=Fröbisch|first3=J.|title=The early evolution of synapsids, and the influence of sampling on their fossil record|journal=Paleobiology|date=2013|volume=39|issue=3|pages=470–490|doi=10.1666/12049}}</ref> Olson's extinction appears to have been the highest Paleozoic peak in extinction rate observed in [[Eureptilia]], exceeding even the End Permian mass extinction.<ref name=Brocklehurst2015>{{cite journal|last1=Brocklehurst|first1=N.|last2=Ruta|first2=M.|last3=Muller|last4=Fröbisch|first4=J.|title=Elevated Extinction Rates as a Trigger for Diversification Rate Shifts: Early Amniotes as a Case Study|journal=Scientific Reports|date=2015|volume=41|pages=43–46|doi=10.1038/srep17104|bibcode=2015NatSR...517104B}}</ref> Amphibians were also particularly hard-hit.<ref name=Benson2013/>
In December 2011, the fossilized remains of the 'youngest' pelycosaur was described by Modesto et al. as from 260 million years ago in South Africa, the first evidence that one of these animals survived Olson’s Extinction.<ref name=Modesto2011> {{cite journal | ref = harv |author=Sean P. Modesto |author2=Roger M. H. Smith |author3=Nicolás E. Campione |author4=Robert R. Reisz |last-author-amp=yes |title=The last "pelycosaur": a varanopid synapsid from the Pristerognathus Assemblage Zone, Middle Permian of South Africa |journal=Naturwissenschaften |year=2011 |volume=98 |issue=12 |doi=10.1007/s00114-011-0856-2 | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/m71171g0607v1ku7/ |pmid=22009069 |pages=1027–34|bibcode=2011NW.....98.1027M}}</ref> This type of animal is called a [[disaster taxon]], an organism that survives a major environmental disruption, perhaps forming the basis for a new adaptive radiation.
=== In the water ===
====Fish==== Extinction rates in fish increased noticeably between the Cisuralian and the Guadalupian, the time of Olson's extinction.<ref name=Friedman2012>{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=M.|last2=Sallan|first2=L.|title=FIVE HUNDRED MILLION YEARS OF EXTINCTION AND RECOVERY: A PHANEROZOIC SURVEY OF LARGE-SCALE DIVERSITY PATTERNS IN FISHES|journal=Palaeontology|date=2012|volume=55|pages=707–742|doi=10.1111/j.1475-4983.2012.01165.x}}</ref> However, origination rates also rose, and so there does not appear to have been any substantial decrease in species richness<ref name=Friedman2012/> Using data on chondrichthyan diversity, Koot showed that there was little substantial decline in diversity until the Middle of the Guadalupian.<ref>Koot, M.B. 2013. Effects of the late Permian mass extinction on chondrichthyan palaeobiodiversity and distribution patterns</ref>
==Recovery== Fauna did not recover fully from Olson's Extinction before the impact of the [[Permian-Triassic extinction event]]. Estimates of recovery time vary, where some authors indicated recovery was prolonged, lasting 30 million years into the Triassic.<ref name="SahneyBenton2008RecoveryFromProfoundExtinction" />
Several important events took place during Olson's Extinction, most notably the origin of [[therapsida|therapsids]], a group that includes the evolutionary ancestors of mammals. Further research on the recently identified primitive therapsid of the Xidagou Formation (Dashankou locality) in China of Roadian age may provide more information on this topic.<ref name="Liu-Rubidge-Li-2009">{{cite journal|ref=harv|last1=Liu|first1=J.|last2=Rubidge|first2=B|last3=Li|first3=J.|title=New basal synapsid supports Laurasian origin for therapsids|journal=Acta Palaeontologica Polonica|year=2009|volume=54|issue=3|pages=393–400|url=http://www.app.pan.pl/archive/published/app54/app20080071.pdf|doi=10.4202/app.2008.0071}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Public Vault | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | partof = Congressional Cemetery | partof_refnum = 69000292 | image = Cong Cem DC Public Vault Feb.JPG | location = [[Southeast, Washington, D.C.|SE]] [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States|U.S.]] | built = 1832–34 | architect =Unknown | architecture = Classical revival | designated_nrhp_type = NHL<ref>{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> | governing_body = }} The '''Public Vault''' at the [[Congressional Cemetery]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] is an early classical revival structure built 1832–34 with funds appropriated by the [[United States Congress]] to store the bodies of government officials and members of the public before burial. About 4,600 individuals were temporarily interred in the vault, including three U.S. presidents, First Lady [[Dolley Madison]], and sixteen congressmen who died while serving in office.<ref>Johnson and Johnson, pp. 67, 139.</ref><ref>A partial list of occupants of the vault is available on the lower part of the page at [http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/site-public-vault "Site - Public Vault"], published by the Association for the Preservation of the Historic Congressional Cemetery.</ref>
As a contributing structure to the cemetery, the vault was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on June 23, 1969, and a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Register of Historic Places listings for June 24, 2011|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/listings/20110624.htm|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|date=June 24, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}</ref>
==Construction== Congress approved an expenditure of $1,000 on July 14, 1832, to build "a substantial brick or stone vault in the Washington Parish Burial Ground, for the temporary interment of members of Congress." Additional appropriations of $1,600 on March 2, 1833, and $194 on June 30, 1834, were approved to complete the vault. These two bills included the name "Public Vault" and allowed the use by members of the public. Use by the government was allowed without further payment, and members of the public were to be charged $5.00 per temporary use. The sexton of [[Christ Church, Washington Parish|Christ Church]] was to be given $1.50 of this sum for his services, with the remainder given to the vestry of Christ Church, which owns the burial ground, "to be expended in the improvement of the grounds and in keeping the same in order."<ref>Johnson and Johnson, pp. 37–38.</ref>
[[File:Public Vault Cong Cem vent holes.JPG|thumb|upright=1.1|left|Vent holes from the interior]] A classical marble facade with baroque scrolls decorate the partially subterranean vault. Double wrought iron doors have the words "PUBLIC VAULT" displayed by means of vent holes.<ref>NHL Nomination, p. 9.</ref> The vault is constructed of [[Aquia Creek sandstone]], which was also used to construct many important early structures in Washington, including the [[White House]], the [[United States Capitol|Capitol]], and the [[Latrobe cenotaphs]] in the cemetery.<ref>Johnson and Johnson, p. 347.</ref> The vault does not have any niches or shelves to hold coffins, rather the coffins were placed on the floor and stacked if necessary.<ref name="PV">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QdMtziloE7k American Artifacts: Congressional Cemetery], American History TV, CSPAN3, on YouTube, accessed April 16, 2012.</ref>
==History== Temporary interments have included three U.S. presidents: [[John Quincy Adams]] (February 26 – March 6, 1848), [[William Henry Harrison]] (April 7 – June 26, 1841), and [[Zachary Taylor]] (July 13 – October 26, 1850). President Harrison stayed in the vault almost three months, more than twice as long as the time he spent as president.<ref name="jnj p139">Johnson and Johnson, p. 139.</ref><ref name="Washian">Josh Swiller, [http://www.washingtonian.com/articles/people/a-walk-through-congressional-cemetery/ A Walk Through Congressional Cemetery], Washingtonian, May 19, 2011.</ref>
[[File:Causten cong cem.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|The Causten family vault, built 1835]] [[Dolley Madison]] was interred in the Public Vault from July 16, 1849, to February 10, 1852, the longest known interment in the vault, while funds were being raised for her re-interment at [[Montpelier (Orange, Virginia)|Montpelier]].<ref name="jnj p139"/> Her body was transferred to the Causten family vault, directly to the west of the Public Vault, for another six years before the funds were raised.<ref name="PV"/> She was briefly joined in May 1852 in the Causten vault by First Lady [[Louisa Catherine Adams]], though it has been reported that Adams was interred in the Public Vault.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Public Vault|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/panorama/2006/12/13/PA2006121300640.html|work=The [[Washington Post]]|accessdate=April 17, 2013|date=December 13, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=First Lady Louisa C. Adams|url=http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/first-lady-louisa-c-adams|publisher=Association for the Preservation of Historic Congressional Cemetery|accessdate=April 17, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009093239/http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/first-lady-louisa-c-adams|archivedate=October 9, 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>Johnson and Johnson, p. 139, unequivocally states that Louisa Adams was interred in the Causten family vault the day after her death.</ref> {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage=[[File:Public Vault exterior.JPG|210px]] | video1 =[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QdMtziloE7k American Artifacts: Congressional Cemetery, Public Vault & Dolley Madison], [[C-SPAN]]<ref name="PV"/> }}
Senator [[John C. Calhoun]] was interred in the Public Vault following a formal funeral and grand procession from the Capitol on April 2, 1850. He was encased in an early version of the [[Fisk metallic burial case|Fisk metallic coffin]] which slowed down decomposition. On April 22 his remains departed the vault for a trip by steam ship to [[Charleston, South Carolina]].<ref name="jnj p76">Johnson and Johnson, p. 76.</ref> While the development of transportation and mortuary technology increased the use of the vault, it also limited its use as well. For example, following [[Henry Clay]]'s death in 1852, his remains were also encased in a Fisk metallic coffin and transported to his home state by railroad without an interval at the Public Vault.<ref name="jnj p76"/>
On February 29, 1844, following an [[USS Princeton disaster of 1844|explosion on the USS ''Princeton'']], Secretary of State [[Abel P. Upshur]], Secretary of the Navy [[Thomas Walker Gilmer]], Commodore Beverly Kennon, and President [[John Tyler]]'s prospective father-in-law, [[David Gardiner (politician)|David Gardiner]], were temporarily interred at the vault.<ref>[http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/secretary-abel-p-upshur-secretary-thomas-wgilmer-commodore-beverly-kennon-hon-david-gardiner-hon-vir Association for the Preservation of the Historic Congressional Cemetery] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009095803/http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/secretary-abel-p-upshur-secretary-thomas-wgilmer-commodore-beverly-kennon-hon-david-gardiner-hon-vir |date=2013-10-09 }}</ref>
Several grand public or state funeral processions ended in front of the Public Vault, after starting at the White House or the Capitol and then moving down Pennsylvania Avenue and E Street SE to the cemetery. These included the funerals for Presidents Harrison, J. Q. Adams, and Taylor; Senator Calhoun; First Ladies Dolley Madison and Louisa Adams; the victims of the USS Princeton disaster; and several other congressmen.<ref name="Chapter 2">Johnson and Johnson, Chapter 2, "The Grand Procession to the National Burial Ground."</ref><ref>[http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/president-william-henry-harrison President William Henry Harrison] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012172257/http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/president-william-henry-harrison |date=2014-10-12 }}, reprinted from The [[National Intelligencer]] by the Association for the Preservation of Historic Congressional Cemetery, accessed April 17, 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/president-john-quincy-adams President John Quincy Adams] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009093956/http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/president-john-quincy-adams |date=2013-10-09 }} includes reprints from 1848 editions of the National Intelligencer, Association for the Preservation of Historic Congressional Cemetery, accessed April 17, 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/president-zachary-taylor President Zachary Taylor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131011091659/http://www.congressionalcemetery.org/president-zachary-taylor |date=2013-10-11 }} includes reprints from 1850 editions of the National Intelligencer, Association for the Preservation of Historic Congressional Cemetery, accessed April 17, 2013.</ref> Some of these processions were two miles long, led by military bands and troops for the funerals of military men, members of both houses of congress and the administration, and pall bearers carefully chosen for political balance to symbolize unity and stability in government.<ref name="Chapter 2"/>
John Quincy Adams rode in a carriage in the funeral procession for President Harrison and wrote in his diary, "the corpse was deposited in the receiving vault - with some difficulty from the excessive crowd, but not the slightest disorder.<ref>Diary entry for April 7, 1841, quoted by Johnson and Johnson, p. 58.</ref>
South Carolina Congressman [[Preston Smith Brooks]] lay in the Public Vault in January 1857, within a year of brutally beating Senator [[Charles Sumner]] with a cane on the floor of the Senate, an attack that is viewed as an omen of the Civil War.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/10/30/fox-news-strolls-congressional-cemetery/ Congressional Cemetery Offers History Lesson], James Rosen, Fox News, October 30, 2009.</ref>
Legend says that [[Lewis Powell (conspirator)|Lewis Powell]] spent a night in the vault while avoiding pursuit for his role in the assassination of President Lincoln.<ref name="Washian"/>
While the Public Vault was an important, if semi-official, national memorial during its first few decades, it was used less and less during the second half of the nineteenth century and during much of the twentieth century was unused.<ref>Johnson and Johnson, p. 67.</ref> During the twentieth century, it became unclear whether the U.S. Government or Christ Church owned the Public Vault and several dozen burial lots. In 1953 a Congressional report suggested that the government clear the record by selling the otherwise unnamed "receiving vault" and the burial lots to the church for $100.<ref>Johnson and Johnson, p. 271.</ref> As late as 2003 the vault was "empty and decaying." It has since been restored with funds provided by the federal government.<ref>Johnson and Johnson, pp. 346–347.</ref> During a c. 2010 Prohibition-based fundraiser, it was used as a cocktail bar.<ref name="PV"/>
